category.catDesc: Used to denote a date calculated by the editor from a regnal year or some other dating method given in the text.

Basil, Bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia
The great light of the Cappadocians

occupation.note: Basil was Bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia .

relation.desc: Severus of Antioch was a follower of Basil of Caesarea.

personGrp.persName: The bishops from outside of Cappadocia who ordained Basil bishop

relation.desc: Severus of Antioch was a follower of Gregory Nazianzen.
Peter sent a letter to Constantine.

event.desc: Between 508 and 511, Severus wrote a letter to Constantine the bishop about the ordination of bishops and clergy in the wake of the Council of Chalcedon.
Asterius the Bishop and those with him came to Severus in Antioch.
Emperor Anastasius sent his formula of satisfaction to Flavian, prelate of Antioch.

John of Claudiopolis, when he received Severus in the house of Patrick, urged Severus to receive the synod of Chalcedon, not as a positive definition of faith, but as a rejection of Nestorius and Eutyches.

event.ana: http://syriaca.org/keyword/anti-nestorian http://syriaca.org/keyword/council-of-chalcedon-451 http://syriaca.org/keyword/anathema http://syriaca.org/keyword/theology http://syriaca.org/keyword/bishops http://syriaca.org/keyword/anti-chalcedonian http://syriaca.org/keyword/arianism http://syriaca.org/keyword/heresy http://syriaca.org/keyword/clergy
event.desc: Severus responded to John by refusing to accept the synod of Chalcedon as a repudiation of Nestorius and Eutyches, because the Chalcedonian creed and the Tome of Leo support Nestorianism; Severus does not believe that anathematizing Eutyches makes the Council of Chalcedon legitimate, because the followers of Arius were still heretics even though they repudiated the teachings of Sabellius.
John asked Severus if Epiphanius had performed his ordinations correctly.
Severus recalled that Epiphanius had been brought up in the monasteries of Perga, practicing a life of virginity.

event.ana: http://syriaca.org/keyword/exile http://syriaca.org/keyword/heresy http://syriaca.org/keyword/council-of-chalcedon-451 http://syriaca.org/keyword/eucharist http://syriaca.org/keyword/bishops http://syriaca.org/keyword/clergy http://syriaca.org/keyword/travel http://syriaca.org/keyword/persecution
event.desc: When Timothy had endured his exile from Alexandria, Epiphanius left his bishopric in Magydum and came to Alexandria, embracing communion with Timothy.
After Timothy had died and the orthodox began enduring persecution again, Epiphanius withdrew to Palestine where he met with Peter of Iberia and began ordaining priests.

event.ana: http://syriaca.org/keyword/ordination http://syriaca.org/keyword/canon-law http://syriaca.org/keyword/greek-fathers http://syriaca.org/keyword/arianism http://syriaca.org/keyword/heresy http://syriaca.org/keyword/bishops
event.desc: Severus argued that by ordaining priests in a diocese that was not his own, Epiphanius was not violating the sacred canons, which only outlaws such behavior in the cases of bishops forcing themselves on other dioceses, citing the examples of Eusebius of Samosata during the controversy of Arius, Theodoret, Basil, and Gregory the Theologian.
Severus believed that he had convinced John to not affirm the council of Chalcedon.
Severus encouraged Constantine to follow his teaching and the advice of Peter the Presbyter and to be alert for John's blacksiding.
Severus wrote letters on similar themes to Oecumenius.

bibl.title: The Sixth Book of the Select Letters of Severus, Patriarch of Antioch in the Syriac Version of Athanasius of Nisibis
Translation, I.1 - II.3
